notesStmt.note: Four front flyleaves, two paper followed by two parchment; two back flyleaves, paper

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a copy of the Gospel of Mark with interlinear and marginal glosses, written in Italy in the middle of the twelfth century. The main text is ruled in drypoint and the marginal glosses are ruled in lead as needed. Many of the marginal glosses are from Jerome (Hier) and Bede (B). Spaces left for initials were not used. A later reader has marked the glosses with minuscule letters.

msItem.title: Prologue to the Gospel of Mark, glossed (not glossa ordinaria)
msItem.incipit: [M]arcus eua[n]g[e]lista dei electus et Petri in baptismate filius ... [fol. 1r]

msItem.title: Gospel of Mark, glossed
msItem.incipit: [I]h[es]u Xpi filii d[e]i sicut scr[i]ptum est in ysaia propheta … [fol. 4v]

supportDesc.extent: iv+119+ii; 225 x 140 mm bound to 235 x 160 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

layoutDesc.layout: Main text written in one column of seventeen lines, ruled in drypoint with double vertical bounding lines; space for gloss on either side of text ruled in lead as needed; some prickings visible; text and gloss written above top line; written area: 148 x 53 mm (main text), 155 x 125 mm (gloss)

decoDesc.decoNote: Spaces for two large initials (fols. 1r, 4v) and small initials beginning chapters left unfilled

binding.p: Nineteenth-century English leather, blind-tooled, marbled endpapers, gold-stamped on spine EVANGEL. SANCTI MARCI.

history.provenance: Rev. John Henry Ellis; his sale London, Sotheby's, June 30, 1913, no. 68, to Maggs; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
